path_1.title: Première année (2018)
path_1.feeling: Intense, relatable pressure-cooker of ambition and friendship.

path_1.title: Hurt Locker, The (2008)
path_1.feeling: Viscerally tense and character-focused, it had me clenched.

path_1.title: Little Miss Sunshine (2006)
path_1.feeling: Warm, offbeat, and gently devastating in all the right ways.

path_1.title: Surf's Up (2007)
path_1.feeling: Charming enough, but slight beyond its stylish gimmick.

path_1.title: How the Grinch Stole Christmas (a.k.a. The Grinch) (2000)
path_1.feeling: Carrey’s rubbery chaos wears thin despite a sweet core.

path_1.title: Walk of Shame (2014)
path_1.feeling: Broad gags over heart

path_1.title: Mississippi Burning (1988)
path_1.feeling: Gripping and angry, if a bit conventional in approach.

path_1.title: Shut Up & Sing (2006)
path_1.feeling: Engaging, clear-eyed look at art, politics, and resilience.

path_1.title: Antichrist (2009)
path_1.feeling: Bold and unsettling, but its provocations felt more punishing than profound.

path_1.title: Twilight Saga: Eclipse, The (2010)
path_1.feeling: Melodramatic love triangle fatigue with little payoff.

path_1.title: Notorious (1946)
path_1.feeling: Silky, perilous romance crafted with masterful suspense.

path_1.title: Get Out (2017)
path_1.feeling: Smart, razor-tense, and wickedly incisive.

path_1.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_1.feeling: Old-fashioned, sweeping comfort with genuine heart.

path_1.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_1.feeling: Relentlessly grim to the point of numbing.

path_1.title: Paris, I Love You (Paris, je t'aime) (2006)
path_1.feeling: A patchwork that charms more often than not.

path_1.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_1.feeling: Stirring ideas and spectacle, even if the sentimentality overreaches.

path_1.title: Sleepers (1996)
path_1.feeling: Heavy and compelling, though occasionally self-serious.

path_1.title: Funny Girl (1968)
path_1.feeling: Star power and tunes, but the romance left me lukewarm.

path_1.title: Knives Out (2019)
path_1.feeling: Clever, lively, and satisfying without feeling smug.

path_1.title: Notebook, The (2004)
path_1.feeling: Earnest, glossy melodrama that didn’t fully move me.

path_1.title: Holiday, The (2006)
path_1.feeling: Cozy and pleasant, if feather-light.

path_1.title: Almost Famous (2000)
path_1.feeling: Glorious, bittersweet coming-of-age with music in its veins.

path_1.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_1.feeling: A kinetic, stylish revenge rush that delights in craft.

path_1.title: The Banshees of Inisherin (2022)
path_1.feeling: Bleakly funny and piercingly humane.

path_1.title: Carrie (1976)
path_1.feeling: Operatic teen horror with real sting.

path_1.title: Shrek 2 (2004)
path_1.feeling: Witty and brisk, though more cute than affecting.
Immersive, nerve-jangling feat that still finds feeling.

path_1.title: Bruce Almighty (2003)
path_1.feeling: A few chuckles, but the broad shtick and sentiment wear out.

path_1.title: American Beauty (1999)
path_1.feeling: Sharp suburban malaise with lingering bite.

path_2.title: Première année (2018)
path_2.feeling: Brisk, stressful study grind with a tender, believable friendship.

path_2.feeling: Nerve-jangling and intimate, a tense character study amid the chaos.

path_2.title: Little Miss Sunshine (2006)
path_2.feeling: Warm, offbeat and gently devastating in all the right ways.

path_2.title: Surf's Up (2007)

path_2.title: Antichrist (2009)
path_2.feeling: Audacious and unsettling, but its cruelty kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Antichrist (2009)
path_5.feeling: Viscerally moody and provocative—adds up more to unease than insight, but I couldn’t look away.

path_5.title: Twilight Saga: Eclipse, The (2010)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, high-stakes romance that left me cold and impatient.

path_5.title: Notorious (1946)
path_5.feeling: Silky, nerve-tightening romance-thriller perfection—I was rapt.

path_5.title: Get Out (2017)
path_5.feeling: A razor-sharp, dread-soaked thrill ride with bite and brains.

path_5.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_5.feeling: Old-school musical sweep that still charms me more than it should.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Relentlessly grim true-crime brutality that felt more punishing than illuminating.

path_5.title: Paris, I Love You (Paris, je t'aime) (2006)
path_5.feeling: A varied, affectionate mosaic—some duds, but the highs glow.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Ambitious and stirring, even if the grandiosity sometimes outpaces the emotion for me.

path_5.title: Sleepers (1996)
path_5.feeling: Dark, cathartic melodrama with enough moral weight to keep me invested.

path_5.title: Funny Girl (1968)
path_5.feeling: Glossy showbiz sweep—likable, if emotionally arm’s-length for me.

path_5.title: Knives Out (2019)
path_5.feeling: Clever, spry whodunit fun with just enough bite to satisfy.

path_5.title: Notebook, The (2004)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, sweeping romance that I found more syrupy than stirring.

path_5.title: Holiday, The (2006)
path_5.feeling: Cozy and watchable, but too polished and predictable to really land.

path_5.title: Almost Famous (2000)
path_5.feeling: Warm, wistful coming-of-age that hums with lived-in music-world texture.

path_5.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_5.feeling: Stylish, propulsive revenge opera—purely intoxicating craft.

path_5.title: The Banshees of Inisherin (2022)
path_5.feeling: Bleakly funny and piercing, a small human rupture that lingered.

path_5.title: Carrie (1976)
path_5.feeling: Operatic teen horror with real ache and atmosphere—I was hooked.

path_5.title: Shrek 2 (2004)
path_5.feeling: Snappy and amiable, though the pop-culture frosting wears thin.
Impressive, immersive craft that moved me more for the form than the story.

path_5.title: Bruce Almighty (2003)
path_5.feeling: High-concept goofs that rarely rise above broad, noisy comfort food.

path_5.title: American Beauty (1999)
path_5.feeling: A polished, unsettling suburban unraveling that still pulls me in.

path_5.title: Première année (2018)
path_5.feeling: Intense, grounded pressure-cooker school drama that favors humane detail over melodrama, which I appreciate.

path_5.title: Hurt Locker, The (2008)
path_5.feeling: A taut, nerve-fraying character study where the tension and moral ambiguity really land.

path_5.title: Little Miss Sunshine (2006)
path_5.feeling: Quirky but tender family road movie that balances prickly humor with real heart.

path_5.title: Surf's Up (2007)
path_5.feeling: The mock-doc vibe and laid-back spirit are charming even if the arc is familiar.

path_5.title: How the Grinch Stole Christmas (a.k.a. The Grinch) (2000)
path_5.feeling: Loud, rubbery holiday antics that wear thin despite a few sweet beats.

path_5.title: Walk of Shame (2014)
path_5.feeling: Broad, strained hijinks with too few laughs to justify the ordeal.

path_5.title: Mississippi Burning (1988)
path_5.feeling: Gripping and well-acted, though its white-savior framing undercuts the power.

path_5.title: Shut Up & Sing (2006)
path_5.feeling: An engaging, human-scale look at protest, backlash, and resilience in the public eye.

path_5.title: Antichrist (2009)
path_5.feeling: Viscerally atmospheric and provocative, compelling even when it feels punishing.

path_5.title: Twilight Saga: Eclipse, The (2010)
path_5.feeling: Soapy stakes and love-triangle wheel-spinning left me mostly unmoved.

path_5.title: Notorious (1946)
path_5.feeling: Silken, nerve-tight Hitchcock romance-thriller that dazzles with precision and longing.

path_5.title: Get Out (2017)
path_5.feeling: Razor-sharp suspense with social bite—smart, uncanny, and deeply satisfying.

path_5.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_5.feeling: Lush, wholehearted musical comfort that still sweeps me up.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Gruesome, oppressive descent that’s effective but veers into lurid misery.

path_5.title: Paris, I Love You (Paris, je t'aime) (2006)
path_5.feeling: A varied, charming mosaic with enough keepers to outweigh the misses.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Grand, heartfelt sci‑fi with stirring ideas that sometimes outpace its seams.

path_5.title: Sleepers (1996)
path_5.feeling: Dark, engrossing melodrama whose powerhouse cast elevates the pulp.

path_5.title: Funny Girl (1968)
path_5.feeling: Glossy and engaging, though the biopic sweep feels more showpiece than soul.

path_5.title: Knives Out (2019)
path_5.feeling: A spry, witty whodunit that juggles character and clockwork plotting with flair.

path_5.title: Notebook, The (2004)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, sweeping romance that moves in moments but leans heavy on sentiment.

path_5.title: Holiday, The (2006)
path_5.feeling: Cozy, well-cast romcom comfort food that goes down easy if unsurprising.

path_5.title: Almost Famous (2000)
path_5.feeling: Warm, wistful coming-of-age that nails the messy thrill of loving music.

path_5.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_5.feeling: Style-drunk, propulsive vengeance opera that thrills even when it indulges.

path_5.title: The Banshees of Inisherin (2022)
path_5.feeling: Bleakly funny and quietly devastating meditation on pride, friendship, and loneliness.

path_5.title: Carrie (1976)
path_5.feeling: Tragic, potent horror whose cruel social sting lingers.

path_5.title: Shrek 2 (2004)
path_5.feeling: Snappy gags and pop flourishes amuse even if it’s more clever than affecting.
Impressive, immersive craft that grips even when the gimmick shows.

path_5.title: Bruce Almighty (2003)
path_5.feeling: High-concept chuckles that scatter as the broadness takes over.

path_5.title: American Beauty (1999)
path_5.feeling: A sharp, uneasy suburban autopsy with performances that cut through the gloss.

path_5.title: Première année (2018)
path_5.feeling: A tense, humane grind of competition that scratches my itch for small, character-first drama.

path_5.title: Hurt Locker, The (2008)
path_5.feeling: Nerve-shredding and lived-in, more about psychology than pyrotechnics—the way I like war stories.

path_5.title: Little Miss Sunshine (2006)
path_5.feeling: Quirky warmth and melancholy in balance—a road movie that genuinely made me care.

path_5.title: Surf's Up (2007)
path_5.feeling: Mock-doc goofs and laid-back vibes make for amiable, lightweight family fun.

path_5.title: How the Grinch Stole Christmas (a.k.a. The Grinch) (2000)
path_5.feeling: Gaudy, overcranked holiday cheer that wore me out more than it charmed me.

path_5.title: Walk of Shame (2014)
path_5.feeling: Broad, strain-for-laughs odyssey that rarely hits my offbeat-comedy sweet spot.

path_5.title: Mississippi Burning (1988)
path_5.feeling: Gripping and enraging in stretches, even if the approach feels a bit blunt at times.

path_5.title: Shut Up & Sing (2006)
path_5.feeling: An engaging, human-sized look at backlash and resilience that kept me invested.

path_5.title: Antichrist (2009)
path_5.feeling: Visceral grief and nature-as-nightmare—boldly executed, tough to love, hard to shake.

path_5.title: Twilight Saga: Eclipse, The (2010)
path_5.feeling: Glossy supernatural melodrama that left me rolling my eyes more than swooning.

path_5.title: Notorious (1946)
path_5.feeling: Silken suspense and thorny romance—Hitchcock at his most intoxicating.

path_5.title: Get Out (2017)
path_5.feeling: A wickedly smart, unsettling social thriller that had me grinning and squirming.

path_5.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_5.feeling: Sweeping, sincere comfort cinema that still hits its emotional crescendos.

path_5.title: Seven (a.k.a. Se7en) (1995)
path_5.feeling: A brutal, queasy descent that’s hard to watch and harder to forget.

path_5.title: Paris, I Love You (Paris, je t'aime) (2006)
path_5.feeling: A mixed bag that adds up to a charming, wistful love letter to a city.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Grand, heartfelt sci‑fi with awe to spare, even if the seams sometimes show.

path_5.title: Sleepers (1996)
path_5.feeling: Dark, morally knotted melodrama that gripped me despite its heaviness.

path_5.title: Funny Girl (1968)
path_5.feeling: Glossy star power and bittersweet beats—engaging more than transporting.

path_5.title: Knives Out (2019)
path_5.feeling: A fizzy, clever whodunit with enough bite to satisfy my mystery cravings.

path_5.title: Notebook, The (2004)
path_5.feeling: Swoony, sincere melodrama that moved me in moments more than as a whole.

path_5.title: Holiday, The (2006)
path_5.feeling: Cozy, polished rom‑com comfort whose sweetness goes down easy if a bit slick.

path_5.title: Almost Famous (2000)
path_5.feeling: Tender, lived‑in coming‑of‑age that made my music-heart swell.

path_5.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_5.feeling: Precision-cut pulp and bravura style—a blood-soaked blast.

path_5.title: The Banshees of Inisherin (2022)
path_5.feeling: Piercingly funny and sad in equal measure—small stakes, huge feelings.

path_5.title: Carrie (1976)
path_5.feeling: Operatic teen terror with a cruel sting and lingering sorrow—right up my alley.

path_5.title: Shrek 2 (2004)
path_5.feeling: Zippy, joke-dense fun that entertains even if it doesn’t linger for me.
Immaculate craft that pulls me through the trenches with propulsive clarity.

path_5.title: Bruce Almighty (2003)
path_5.feeling: High‑concept, broad laughs that amuse in spots but feel thin overall.

path_5.title: American Beauty (1999)
path_5.feeling: A sharp, uneasy suburban dissection that still lands its emotional blows.
